Award.AwardTitle: Conservation law-based models for overturning circulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will develop mathematical and computational tools for the conceptual modeling of fluid mixing, and apply them to the representation of climate-related processes that are not yet fully understood. The novel tools involve the use of non-standard conservation laws, so as to represent mixing through fluid entrainment at breaking waves. These will be applied to two-layer scenarios, the simplest models for overturning circulations, and to continuously stratified shear flows. The former provides useful settings to study gravity currents, entrainment into the ocean's mixed layer and circulations such as those associated with the sea-breeze, coastal upwelling and the Hadley cells of tropical convection. The latter provides a sophisticated mathematical scenario to answer questions about the formation of mixed layers and their re-stratification, and the mechanisms behind the creation of staircase stratification profiles.

In its geophysical applications, this award will enhance our understanding of mixing and overturning circulations at many scales, including the storm-driven entrainment of water from the thermocline into the ocean's mixed layer and the elucidation of the leading factors determining the extent of the tropics. This is particularly relevant, as there has been substantial recent interest in determining whether, under global warming scenarios, the Hadley cells would expand, yielding climatic changes such as higher-latitude desertification. If a model proposed here is correct, the extent of the cells is due to the trapping of diurnal waves by the Coriolis effect, which makes such an expansion much less plausible. On the mathematical side, new problems in partial differential equations will be addressed, including non-standard systems of conservation laws and shocks and vertical discontinuities in continuously stratified media. The project will create opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students to be trained in interdisciplinary research, at the intersection between applied mathematics, computational science, applied physics and the geosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding and quantifying fluid mixing is a key ingredient in predicting climate variability, as fluid mixing determines the distribution of, among other quanties, the temperature and salinity in the ocean, and temperature, humidity, ozone and aerosols in the atmosphere. This project developed a new approach to the mathematical modeling of fluid mixing and overturning circulations, through nonstandard systems of conservation laws. For instance, in the presence of mixing, ocean layers do not preserve their individual masses, as water from one layer may be entrained and mixed into another. Yet other quantities, such as global mass, momentum and energy are conserved. The challenge that this proposal addressed is how to use only these truely conserved quantities to describe the evolution of a fluid system, including a quantification of mixing. This was achieved through a combination of tools in partial differential equations -particularly in the study of breaking waves- and optimization. The resulting model yielded results in good agreement with laboratory obervations of multilayer flows.

In addition to the development of dynamical models, this project was concerned with the analysis of data. A new tool was brought to bear on this: the mathematical theory of optimal transport, which provides a flexible, robust and first-principled methodology to the explanation of variability. This finds application beyond climate science, in fields as diverse as medicine -where it can, for instance, help discriminate what fraction of the variability in a blood test can be attributed to external factors, such as age and gender, and what fraction to the ailment under scrutiny- and economics.

Ph.D. students were trained in mathematical modeling and data analysis, working on their dissertations under the direction of the PI on the topics of this project. The PI, students, postdoctoral fellows and visitors also met weekly in a research seminar to discuss general issues in data science. The  results of this project were disseminated through scientific publications in peer-reviewed journals and presentations in scientific conferences.
